pull_request.title: Mark more stateless operators
pull_request.body:
## Category:
<!---
Please pick one from below:
**Bug fix** (*non-breaking change which fixes an issue*)
**Breaking change** (*fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected*)
**Refactoring** (*Redesign of existing code that doesn't affect functionality*)
**Other** (*e.g. Documentation, Tests, Configuration*)
--->
**New feature** (*non-breaking change which adds functionality*)

## Description:
<!---
Please explain what kind of change is in this PR and why it is submitted.
Any additional context or description of the solution is welcomed.
Examples:
- It fixes a bug *bug description*
- It adds new feature needed because of *why we need this feature*
- Refactoring to improve *what*
- The *new feature/bugfix* uses *a new data structure/algorithm* to do *X* instead of *Y*.
--->

By default, an operator throws "Checkpointing unsupported" error on an attempt to save/restore checkpoint. Operators without state should inherit from `StatelessOperator` to indicate that checkpoint save/restore are no-ops.

In this PR I mark remaining stateless operators by making them inherit from `StatelessOperator`. For each operator a simple python test is added to verify that it's in fact stateless.

## Additional information:

### Affected modules and functionalities:
<!--- Describe here what was changed, added, removed. --->

### Key points relevant for the review:
I marked image decoder base classes (`NvJPEGDecoder` and `HostDecoder`) as `Stateless`, because their random-cropping variants override `Save/RestoreState` and have checkpointing implemented.

### Tests:
<!--- Describe the test coverage of the introduced change.

If you select `Existing tests apply` option, please list which test cases cover the introduced
functionality. For example:
- test_operator_gaussian_blur.py: test_gaussian*
- tensor_list_test.cc: TensorListVariableBatchSizeTest*
--->
- [ ] Existing tests apply
- [x] New tests added
  - [x] Python tests
  - [ ] GTests
  - [ ] Benchmark
  - [ ] Other
- [ ] N/A


<!---
At this point you can hit "Create".
The checklist below shall be filled in the created PR.

issue.title: How to do item assignment in Pipeline?
issue.body:
### Describe the question.

Hi DALI Group, 
I'd like to mask the down half of image with 0. On numpy or pytorch, I can do `x[:3, H//2:]=0`, assuming that the shape of `x` is `[6, H, W]`, and it is composed of 2 images, and I only want to mask the first image. When I read the docs, I find the function `fn.erase` might do it. But I don't know how to use it properly. Could you plz give me some advice?

### Check for duplicates

- [X] I have searched the [open bugs/issues](https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/issues) and have found no duplicates for this bug report

comment.body:
Hi @mzient, thank u for your patient response. In my data process pipeline, I have to make a copy of `part2` as the label of model training. So I have to add some lines to snippet you wrote, call `code1`, 
```python
part1 = fn.stack(*frames[:self.syncnet_T], axis=0, axis_name='F')  # the layout now is FHWC
part2 = fn.stack(*frames[self.syncnet_T:], axis=0, axis_name='F')
# now erase the lower half of the images in part2
y = fn.copy(part2)
part2 = fn.erase(part2,
                 normalized=True,
                 anchor=np.array([[0.5, 0]]),
                 shape=np.array([[0.5, 1.0]]),
                 axis_names="HW")
frames = fn.cat(part1, part2, axis=-1)
frames = frames * (1.0/255)  # no need to call normalize for simple scaling
frames = fn.transpose(frames, perm=[3, 0, 1, 2])
y = y * (1.0/255)
y = fn.transpose(y, perm=[3, 0, 1, 2])
```
So which one (compared to my snippet before, call `code2`) is more efficient? I prefer `code1`

issue.title: Possible Memory leak with multi gpu training?
issue.body:
### Version

1.21

### Describe the bug.

I used the code from tutorial to train ImageNet (https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/blob/main/docs/examples/use_cases/pytorch/resnet50/main.py) , I have six 1080ti gpus.

However, the memory comsumption of 6th gpu was always larger and increasing when training, and would throw the OOM exception in the middle of training.

for example, here are my nvidia smi, the memory comsumption of 6th gpu was larger when compared to others.

![image](https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/assets/1567200/d71e2daa-1697-463b-9685-b672bbb63204)

Any idea?

### Minimum reproducible example

```shell
Ref https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/blob/main/docs/examples/use_cases/pytorch/resnet50/main.p
```


### Relevant log output

_No response_

### Other/Misc.

_No response_

### Check for duplicates

- [X] I have searched the [open bugs/issues](https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/issues) and have found no duplicates for this bug report

comment.body:
@twmht 
I understand that reaching OOM after so long makes the problem hard to challange and is frustrating. This behaviour is an unfortunate consequence of randomized processing and is hard to avoid. However, to adjust the batch size easier, you can do the following:

1. Replace `decoders.image_random_crop` with just `decoders.image` in your pipeline. This will eliminate the random cropping and simulate the most pessimistic case in which 100% of every image is decoded.
2. Run the pipeline for a few epochs. As there's no random cropping present, the peak memory usage should be reached relatively quick. You have 6 shards, so after at most 6 epochs the memory usage should stabilize.
3. If during (2) you reach OOM or the memory usage is dangerously high, try reducing your batch size by 30-50% and try again.
4. Once the memory usage is satsifying, use `decoders.image_random_crop` again. The memory usage of randomly cropped images should never exceed the memory usage of uncropped ones, so you shouldn't get out of memory anymore.

I hope this way you'll be able to adjust your batch size faster.

> this issue occurs on a specific GPU, while other GPUs seem to not have this problem

On our side the issue occured on other GPUs too, so I assume you're always observing it on 6th GPU due to the fact that DALI uses pseudorandom generators with seeds being the same for each run, meaning that pipeline's "randomness" will behave the same way on each run. If you wish, you can provide us with complete Python file that you are using. I'll then run it on our side to test if I can reproduce the unlucky 6th GPU problem.

issue.title: How to randomly crop two images
issue.body:
### Describe the question.

I want to use Dali to process images in semantic segmentation, so how can I ensure that the images and labels are the same area after random cropping

code:
![image](https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/assets/49420977/1fe527ea-4d7e-405d-b561-6394372ba5f2)

error:
![image](https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/assets/49420977/320144ee-5a3c-427f-b615-e92e01d99cf4)


### Check for duplicates

- [X] I have searched the [open bugs/issues](https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/issues) and have found no duplicates for this bug report

comment.body:
Hi @umie0128,

I'm sorry to hear that you obtained lower accuracy. What I can suggest is to visually examine the pipeline output to make sure you achieve the expected results.
Regarding random conversion between RGB and BGR, you can use [the color conversion operator](https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/dali/user-guide/docs/operations/nvidia.dali.fn.color_space_conversion.html#nvidia-dali-fn-color-space-conversion) together with [the conditional execution](https://docs.nvidia.com/deeplearning/dali/user-guide/docs/pipeline.html#conditional-execution).

issue.title: Possible Memory leak with multi gpu training?
issue.body:
### Version

1.21

### Describe the bug.

I used the code from tutorial to train ImageNet (https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/blob/main/docs/examples/use_cases/pytorch/resnet50/main.py) , I have six 1080ti gpus.

However, the memory comsumption of 6th gpu was always larger and increasing when training, and would throw the OOM exception in the middle of training.

for example, here are my nvidia smi, the memory comsumption of 6th gpu was larger when compared to others.

![image](https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/assets/1567200/d71e2daa-1697-463b-9685-b672bbb63204)

Any idea?

### Minimum reproducible example

```shell
Ref https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/blob/main/docs/examples/use_cases/pytorch/resnet50/main.p
```


### Relevant log output

_No response_

### Other/Misc.

_No response_

### Check for duplicates

- [X] I have searched the [open bugs/issues](https://github.com/NVIDIA/DALI/issues) and have found no duplicates for this bug report

comment.body: I find it difficult to adjust the batch size because it takes several tens of epochs of training before encountering an 'Out of Memory' situation. Training for many epochs can take several days, and this issue occurs on a specific GPU, while other GPUs seem to not have this problem. This results in unused memory on the other GPUs, which seems like a waste. This can be quite challenging for users.

issue.title: Add type hints for ExternalSource, Python Functions, TFRecord Reader, math module
issue.body:
## Category: **New feature**
<!---
Please pick one from below:
**Bug fix** (*non-breaking change which fixes an issue*)
**New feature** (*non-breaking change which adds functionality*)
**Breaking change** (*fix or feature that would cause existing functionality to not work as expected*)
**Refactoring** (*Redesign of existing code that doesn't affect functionality*)
**Other** (*e.g. Documentation, Tests, Configuration*)
--->


## Description:
Add annotations to operators with custom Python wrappers:
* External source
* TFRecord reader
* Python function family
* nvidia.dali.math module
* ops.Compose

Add stub file for nvidia.dali.tfrecord module.

Add return type annotations to the Pipeline.run function.
The TensorList types again are not fully visible due to being generated 
by backend at runtime, next step should provide a dedicated stub file
or alternative implementation.

The stubs are based on the output of mypy `stubgen` and the 
`nvidia.dali.ops._signatures._gen_[fn/ops]_signature`.

The stub generation is reworked, first grouping the operators into 
4 categories, so the generated stubs contain imports first. 
We utilize the fact that the operators with custom Python wrappers
have dedicated implementation modules now, and reexpose them
in the stubs, allowing the type hints to be picked up.

The external source has non-trivial defaults, expressed mostly via `None`
and cross-dependent on other parameters, so creating a meaningful
annotations there is hard.
There are two overloads provided for the `external_source` function,
allowing to disambiguate between the single and multiple outputs
(when `num_outputs` parameter was used, and the return type is 
always a tuple). Such distinction can't be easily made in the ops API.

TODO:
* Numba and Pytorch function are left for a followup as they require 
   a lot of code movement to accommodate for the module structure.


## Additional information:

### Affected modules and functionalities:
Several operators, Pipeline.run, stub generation.



### Key points relevant for the review:
If the annotations are ok.
